repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body: **Problem**: there is no way to see diagnostic count in stock neovim **Solution**: add buffer diagnostic count to the default statusline **Context**: There is [interest](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/28809#issuecomment-2840298390) in trying this out. I tried to keep the implementation to a bare minimum. **Preview**: Statusline displays current buffer diagnostics just before cursor position information. Different diagnostics are displayed based on what window statusline belongs to. Diagnostics kinds with 0 count are omitted from the status line --- I will add tests and news entry once settled on the implementation.

comment_data.body:
Not sure if this is a good idea to do by default as it can either lead to more redraws than necessary or in the worst case interfere with messages that are being polled (like lsp status)

I think ideally the full `DiagnosticChanged` autocmd should only be setup on demand if the default status line is actually used. Otherwise everyone pays the cost for the string formatting.

comment_data.body:
> Oh, should we introduce this as vim.diagnostic.status() (compare vim.lsp.status()) ?

Makes sense. Looking at the implementation `vim.lsp.status()` displays messages from all clients for all buffers. `vim.diagnostic.status()` would have to be local to the current or passed in buffer for starters, can be expanded to display all diagnostics if needed.

If we decided to go with `vim.diagnostic.status()` would it be used in the statusline as is i.e. 
```lua
vim.opt.status = '... %{luaeval("vim.diagnostic.status()")} ...'
```

> And yes, making this conditional on whether the default statusline is used, makes sense.

I've updated the code to sub/unsub when statusline is changed

comment_data.body:
> `vim.lsp.status()` displays messages from all clients for all buffers.

vim.diagnostics.status() doesn't need to exactly match how lsp.status works; it's just a reference for the "shape" + name.



> If we decided to go with `vim.diagnostic.status()` would it be used in the statusline as is i.e.

I think so. And then the [default 'statusline'](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/6577d72d819dde32abeacd6a72d6ba64483f7ddc/src/nvim/options.lua#L8577-L8584) will reflect this too, which is Good. If there are "performance" issues, those need to be fixed internally in `status()`, e.g. by debouncing or whatever.

comment_data.body: This file is generated, and the option should be changed in `src/nvim/options.lua` I believe.

> I'm not 100% sure, but I think setting bufnr to 0 is the same as vim.diagnostic.count(vim.api.nvim_get_current_buf())

Its the exact same. When you call `vim.diagnostic.count()` with a number as bufnr, it eventually calls `vim._resolve_bufnr()`, which does just that:
```
function vim._resolve_bufnr(bufnr)
  if bufnr == nil or bufnr == 0 then
    return vim.api.nvim_get_current_buf()
  end
  vim.validate('bufnr', bufnr, 'number')
  return bufnr
end
```
Note: Calling it with nil instead does not reach this part and instead returns diagnostics for all buffers.

comment_data.body: while evaluating  expression in `%{ }`, the current buffer is set to buffer whose statusline is being drawn, which is what we want for vim.diagnostic.count(0) to work correctly. I think passing in g:actual_curbuf (which is, oddly, a string) is not what we want, we want to draw diagnostics per buffer don't we? from my experiments I found that not passing in g:actual_curbuf is what *I* wanted anyway - otherwise I had the same diagnostic count in each buffer statusline (including help buffers, which does not make sense) due to passing in  g:actual_curbuf.

comment_regular_data.body: You can use `vim.diagnostic.count()` to get the counts.
screenshot helps a lot with these kinds of changes :)

I suggest we use capital letters E,W,I instead of small ones. As they take up full height as the number next to it (E:2 looks more symatric then e:2 ) . .And I think plugins are also used to using them. I think I've been seeing them since syntastic/ale days.

There are already some standard highlight groups for shoing Error and Warning states like ErrorMsg, WarningMsg should the statusline use them in this case?

Doing it from `vim.diagnostics.status()` makes sense. Also, I think we should consider if we would introduce e new namespace for all statusling things., Instead of scattering them in different parts of the system. Like `vim.ui.status.diagnostics()`  or `vim.status.diagnostics`? So later stuff can be put under that status module.

I'm not sure a `status()` is warranted. Counts are already conveniently exposed via `diagnostic.count`, so all one has to do is the str formatting - which people likely want to customize - especially the `E` and `W`.

I think what would have higher leverage is to support `statusline` being a table of segments, where each segment is either a string as is or a lua function so one doesn't have to go through `luaeval` or buffer variables.

> consider if we would introduce e new namespace for all statusling things., Instead of scattering them in different parts of the system. Like `vim.ui.status.diagnostics()` or `vim.status.diagnostics`?

can consider that later, if it becomes obvious that it is needed. but for now, let's continue the existing pattern. subsystem-specific stuff usually lives in the subsystem's own module. the fact that each subsystem has common features doesn't mean that it should be "inverted" such that the common feature now has its own module with per-subsystem names.

> I'm not sure a `status()` is warranted. Counts are already conveniently exposed via `diagnostic.count`, so all one has to do is the str formatting

the current logic in this PR is 20+ lines. `status()` allows people to easily plug-in diagnostics status into custom statuslines, instead of copy-pasting the logic. and we can always add parameters later if it makes sense (for formatting, etc).



> support `statusline` being a table of segments, where each segment is either a string as is or a lua function

that sounds out of scope for this topic, unless I misunderstood

> the fact that each subsystem has common features doesn't mean that it should be "inverted" such that the common feature now has its own module with per-subsystem names.

I didn't mean that. We wish to add more stuff to the statusline. All of them might not have a designated module where they'd clearly belong. The progress integrator, for example. Most of the things added, I assume, will be done in Lua. Keeping a standard place for statusline gives us at least 2 advantages without any disadvantage as far as I see:
 - When adding new things, it is clear where they'll go in the future.
 - If user want to reuse these modules in their custom statusline, they are easy to find.

I was planning on making a similar pr, adding diagnostics in the default statusline. So, just sharing my thoughts

> We wish to add more stuff to the statusline. All of them might not have a designated module where they'd clearly belong. The progress integrator,

makes sense, but probably shouldn't block this pr. can revisit later.

> I suggest we use capital letters E,W,I instead of small ones. As they take up full height as the number next to it (E:2 looks more symatric then e:2 ) . .And I think plugins are also used to using them. I think I've been seeing them since syntastic/ale days.
> 
> There are already some standard highlight groups for shoing Error and Warning states like ErrorMsg, WarningMsg should the statusline use them in this case?

Or as @clason has advocated in other PRs, use `vim.diagnostic.config().signs.text` for this (which defaults to E, W, H, I) so it's user-configurable. For highlighting, `vim.diagnostic().config().signs.numhl` can probably be used.

Thanks for the input everyone. I'll update this PR in a couple of days

* migrate it to use `vim.diagnostic.status()`
* use `vim.diagnostic.config().signs.text` for the characters

I've updated the PR to have `vim.diagnostic.status()` instead that returns a formatted string with current buffer diagnostics and used in the default statusline I am not clear on 2 things: 1. Currently the statusline is not updated automatically when diagnostics have changed. Should we subscribe to diagnostic if this function is ever called? Are there better ways of doing this? 2. I am not sure on how to call `vim.diagnostic.status()` in the statusline expression _once_ and pad it on the right only if it is a non empty string. I've hardcoded a space there. Perhaps there's an nicer way of doing this.

>     2. I am not sure on how to call `vim.diagnostic.status()` in the statusline expression _once_ and pad it on the right only if it is a non empty string. I've hardcoded a space there. Perhaps there's an nicer way of doing this.

You can put the function call into an item group `"%(%{v:lua.vim.diagnostic.status()} %)"`. This way, the space on the right only appears if the return value is not empty.
However, this expression gets evaluated every time the statusline is redrawn.

> Currently the statusline is not updated automatically when diagnostics have changed. Should we subscribe to diagnostic if this function is ever called? Are there better ways of doing this?

I tried this and it seems to work for me (with lua-ls). But it can probably be done with:

```lua
function M.status()
  -- first checking if it exists seems like the right thing, but I don't know if it 
  -- actually makes any difference in speed
  if not vim.api.nvim_create_augroup('nvim.diagnostic.status', { clear = false }) then
    vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd('DiagnosticChanged', {
      group = vim.api.nvim_create_augroup('nvim.diagnostic.status', {}),
      callback = vim.cmd.redrawstatus,
      -- or with nvim__redraw, don't know what's preferred:
      -- callback = vim.api.nvim__redraw({ statusline = true }),
      desc = '...',
    })
  end

  local counts = M.count(0)
  local user_signs = vim.tbl_get(M.config(), 'signs', 'text') or {}
  local signs = vim.tbl_extend('keep', user_signs, { 'E', 'W', 'I', 'H' })
  local result_str = vim
    .iter(pairs(counts))
    :map(function(severity, count)
      return ('%s:%s'):format(signs[severity], count)
    end)
    :join(' ')

  return result_str
end
```

I've tried @yochem suggestion though the if condition always evaluates to false. An alternative with a global variable also did not work for me for some reason

```lua
local has_autoupdate_diagnostic = false

function M.status()
  if not has_autoupdate_diagnostic then
    vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd('DiagnosticChanged', {
      group = vim.api.nvim_create_augroup('nvim.diagnostic.status', {}),
      command = 'redrawstatus',
    })
    has_autoupdate_diagnostic = true
  end

  ...
```

At this point I am unclear on why the autocmd is not being set. I also noticed that `vim.print` or `vim.notify` calls are not send to messages when placed inside this function

This rather simple condition works to check if it's used in the statusline:
```lua
function M.status()
  if vim.o.statusline:find('vim.diagnostic.status') then
    vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd('DiagnosticChanged', {
      group = vim.api.nvim_create_augroup('nvim.diagnostic.status', {}),
      command = 'redrawstatus',
    })
  end
  ...
```

Using the default statusline, `:autocmd nvim.diagnostic.status` shows the autocmd:

```
--- Autocommands ---
nvim.diagnostic.status  DiagnosticChanged
    *         redrawstatus
```

While with `set stl='hi'` in your config, the autocmd is not set.

That said, I think it's also fine to just remove the condition. It probably doesn't add much performance overhead to redraw the statusline on diagnostic changes, and I don't think this function will be used in other cases than the statusline anyways.

> This rather simple condition works to check if it's used in the statusline:

I am unclear on why, but even when I remove the condition, calls to `nvim_create_autocmd`. The output of `:autocmd DiagnosticChanged` is empty. I moved it outside of the `M.status` for this reason. I am not a fan of this module having a side effect but it works now. the doc is updated as well. If there are no other concerns for implementation, I am happy to update the tests and mark this PR as ready for review

@justinmk Do you think it would make sense to include workspace diagnostics now that #34262 is merged? I'm not sure how other editors do this, but I can imagine that full workspace diagnostics in the statusline is also useful, especially if a user opens Nvim instances on project-basis.

EDIT: probably better suited for a followup.

> include workspace diagnostics now that #34262 is merged?

should be a followup
Definitely followup, but lest I forget: could present it as `E: 4/18` (buffer / workspace) to keep the presentation concise.

This should be review ready now.

The two items that I'd like some feedback

1. I still think neovim should include an autocommand to refresh statusline on diagnostic change. Otherwise the diagnostics will likely be frequently outdated.
2. the test `test/functional/core/channels_spec.lua` fails. The failed equality check varies. I can see in the github actions it gets [one message](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/actions/runs/16081758226/job/45387456589?pr=33723#step:10:9738) `*[1] = 'E5108: Lua: vim/_init_packages.lua:0: module 'vim.diagnostic' not ' } } }. While locally I get a different message `*[1] = 'E5108: Lua: vim/_editor.lua:0: module 'vim.deprecated.hea' } } }`. It is not clear to me how the changes could have affected this test so would appreciate any pointers.

oh, i see the test you were asking about:

```
FAILED   test/functional/core/channels_spec.lua @ 199: channels can use stdio channel with pty
...
     *[1] = 'E5108: Lua: vim/_init_packages.lua:0: module 'vim.diagnostic' not fo' } } }
```

The reason it's failing is because 'statusline' now eagerly requests `vim.diagnostic`, but that's not available in `nvim -u NONE` contexts.

This is signaling a realistic problem (when users run `nvim -u NONE`). I think the best way to handle it is to change the statusline item to something like 

    %{luaeval('not vim.diagnostic')?'':v:lua.vim.diagnostic.status()}

Kind of ugly but we can revisit in the future.

The functionality seem good at this point.

There are now only 2 failing jobs left.

1. docs lint [fails to parse](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/actions/runs/16253940403/job/45887418751?pr=33723#step:5:163) the new long default status line value
2. functional test for channel spec runs into a [similar E5108  issue](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/actions/runs/16253940411/job/45887425671?pr=33723#step:10:9781) where diagnostic is not available for `nvim -u NONE`. This is surprising given that the access to diagnostic in statusline is now guarded
Maybe just don't include the default value of 'statusline' in help, like 'errorformat'?
